awd_titl_txt: RUI: Development of new polyvalent iodine reagents
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Viktor V. Zhdankin of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at University of Minnesota Duluth is developing new classes of oxidizing agents. Oxidizing agents are important tools for the construction of a wide variety of molecules. The approach Professor Zhdankin and his group is developing utilizes polyvalent iodine compounds because they are efficient and environmentally more "friendly" that the reagents currently used. The iodine based systems work because iodine is one of the heaviest elements in the Periodic Table classified as a non-metal. Hence, these more sustainable reagents mimic the structural features and reactivity pattern heavy, frequently toxic transition metals they are being used to replace. It is also important to note that the reagents are new. As such, they can be used to not only replicate existing methods, but also to develop entirely new reactions. The project lies at the interface of organic and inorganic chemistry and it is well suited for undergraduate education as well as for training of scientists at all levels. Professor Zhdankin's group has a long history of providing the highest level of education and training for students underrepresented in science. 

Professor Zhdankin and his group are pursuing a broad study of new, metal-free, iodine-mediated reactions. In this effort, they are searching for new hypervalent reagents, and they are exploring the new modes of reactivity those reagents enable.  Specific objectives of this project include the study of arylbenziodoxaboroles as efficient benzyne precursors, the development of new carbene precursors based on phenolic iodonium salts, the study of arylation reactions with phenolic diaryliodonium salts, and the study of phosphonium-iodonium ylides as reagents for synthesis of trifluoromethyl-substituted alkenes. In a second effort, Professor Zhdankin is searching for stable and potentially useful hypervalent iodine complexes with mesoionic carbenes. The new synthetic methodology based on organohypervalent iodine chemistry is contributing to environmentally benign methods for chemical synthesis as it utilizes non-toxic compounds of iodine as catalysts or recyclable reagents in aqueous solutions.  Successful development of this methodology is having an impact on how the synthesis of molecules relevant to the pharmaceutical, chemical, and agricultural industries is approached. This project provides excellent training to students at all levels of education including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-supported research project has been aimed at the exploration of the chemistry of polyvalent iodine compounds, which are efficient and environmentally benign oxidizing reagents with numerous applications in organic synthesis.  Organic compounds of polyvalent iodine, which are also known under the general name of hypervalent iodine reagents, have chemical properties analogous to the derivatives of transition metals, but without the toxicity and environmental problems of these heavy metal congeners.  In the course of this project, several new hypervalent iodine reagents were developed. For example, new efficient benzyne precursors, pseudocyclic arylbenziodoxaboroles, were prepared and investigated. Benzyne is an important reactive intermediate, widely utilized in chemical research and industry. The common, existing benzyne precursors require activation by heating to high temperature or by using environmentally damaging chemicals in organic solvents. Pseudocyclic arylbenziodoxaboroles can generate benzyne intermediates by simple treatment with water at room temperature, which is particularly important for working with sensitive organic substrates including biomolecules.

During this project, significant research efforts have been dedicated to the development of new synthetic methodologies utilizing iodine and its compounds.  Experimentally simple and environmentally friendly, metal-free procedure for preparation of practically important isoxazoles was developed. This approach allows efficient and environmentally safe access to important heterocyclic compounds, which are widely used as building blocks in synthetic organic chemistry and pharmaceutical industry.  

The results of this project during 2018-2023 were published in 23 peer-reviewed publications (including 9 reviews and accounts summarizing NSF-funded research), reported as 16 presentations at national and international meetings, and presented as 4 invited lectures at international conferences and 10 research seminars in different universities. In addition, three lectures on the NSF-sponsored research in the area of iodine chemistry were presented to the non-science students and general public. 

This research has contributed to the field of chemistry through discovery of new classes of hypervalent iodine compounds and development of synthetic methodologies based on these compounds.  New synthetic methodology based on iodine chemistry is a valuable contribution to environmentally benign methods for chemical synthesis as it utilizes non-toxic compounds of iodine as catalysts or recyclable reagents in aqueous solutions.  Successful development of this methodology will have an impact on any area of activity in which the synthesis of molecules is needed, such as the pharmaceutical, chemical, agricultural industry, and the biological and chemical research activities.  This project provided excellent training to 9 undergraduates, 7 M.S. students, and one postdoctoral fellow.  All these students have received excellent research experience and training in synthetic organic chemistry, coauthored scientific papers, and gave numerous scientific presentations on their research. In addition to students, a science teacher from Marshall High School in Duluth, has extensively participated in this research. Numerous visits of Marshall School students to instrumental labs at UMD were arranged. This project actively involved female students and underrepresented minority students.

 


Last Modified: 08/07/2023
Modified by: Viktor V Zhdankin
